title: Augmented Reality Assembly Guidance Using Robust Contour-Based Pose Tracking
author: Jixiang Chen (Beijing Institute of Technology), Jing Chen (Beijing Institute of Technology), Kai Liu (Beijing Institute of Technology), Haochen Chang (Sun Yat-Sen University), Shanfeng Fu (Beijing Institute of Technology), Jian Yang (Beijing Institute of Technology)
relevance_why: The contour-based pose tracking method could enhance audio-related applications that depend on precise spatial awareness and object recognition in augmented reality environments.
background: This paper addresses robust 6 Degree of Freedom (DoF) pose tracking of objects in augmented reality assembly scenarios, particularly in challenging conditions involving noise and occlusion.
contribution: This paper introduces a robust contour-based pose tracking method utilizing a fan-shaped search strategy to improve correspondence accuracy, achieving significant performance improvements in noisy environments.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods struggled with robust contour matching in cluttered scenarios, often failing during noisy sequences and occlusions.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work enhances tracking performance by utilizing a mixed probability model for corner correspondences and integrating a CPU-only approach for rotationally symmetric objects.

key_innovation: A unique point-to-distribution searching strategy is employed, allowing for better contour matching by modeling shape and noise uncertainties.
real_world_impact: The proposed method can significantly improve real-time object tracking in augmented reality applications, thereby enhancing user interactions in intelligent manufacturing and medical settings.
limitations: The authors do not specifically mention limitations; however, challenges with highly displaced objects or extreme occlusions may still exist.

new_terms.6 Degree of Freedom (6DoF): **6 Degree of Freedom (6DoF)** refers to the freedom of movement of a rigid body in three-dimensional space, allowing translation along three axes (x, y, z) and rotation around three axes (roll, pitch, yaw).
new_terms.mixed probability distribution: **Mixed probability distribution** is a statistical model that combines multiple probability distributions to accommodate uncertainty and improve robustness in tracking tasks.
